weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

countermeasure.name: Apply data masking rules to columns
countermeasure.desc:
To implement data masking and ensure sensitive information within BigQuery datasets is securely exposed based on user roles, a cloud engineer should follow the steps below:

  1. Understand the Data Masking feature of BigQuery, which allows you to create policies that conditionally mask column data for users without the necessary permissions. Review the GCP BigQuery Column Data Masking Introduction to get a comprehensive overview of how this feature works and its benefits.
  2. Identify sensitive columns in your tables that require data masking. This involves understanding data types and the sensitivity level of information stored, such as Personally Identifiable Information (PII).
  3. Create and define data masking policies using BigQuery's data masking functionality. Policies are rules that define how columns will be masked when accessed by unauthorized users. You can mask entire values, partially mask them, or provide a default masked value.
  4. Assign roles and permissions to your users. This involves using Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles to define who should be able to see unmasked data versus who should only view masked data. Reference the IAM overview documentation for detailed guidance on setting and managing roles and permissions.
  5. Test your masking policies to ensure they operate correctly by viewing the data from different user accounts with diverse roles. Make sure that unauthorized users can only access masked data while authorized users can see the full data.
  6. Regularly review and update your data masking policies and IAM roles as your organizational needs and datasets evolve to maintain a robust security posture. Keeping your security policies up-to-date is critical for minimizing the risk of information disclosure.

For further information, refer to the BigQuery documentation where you can find additional details and examples to help you implement and refine your data masking strategy effectively.

countermeasure.name: Build a hierarchy of data classes with policy tags
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the protection of sensitive data in Google BigQuery, cloud engineers are advised to utilize policy tags for defining access controls at the column level. This approach allows for fine-grained control over who can access specific pieces of data, ensuring that sensitive information is only available to users with the appropriate permissions.

Policy tags in BigQuery are part of the Data Catalog service, which provides a centralized way to manage data access and enforce compliance across your datasets. Here's a step-by-step guide to implementing column-level access control with policy tags:

  1. Create Policy Tags: In the Google Cloud Console, navigate to the Data Catalog service. Here, you can create a taxonomy and define a set of policy tags that represent different levels of sensitivity or compliance requirements for your data. This step is crucial in classifying your data based on the security and access policies you intend to enforce.
  2. Assign Policy Tags to Columns: Once your policy tags are created, associate these tags with the specific columns in your BigQuery tables. This is done by using the BigQuery Console or via the BigQuery API. By tagging columns, you identify which data elements require restricted access and thereby lay the groundwork for precise security control.
  3. Configure IAM Permissions: Use Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles to assign users or groups the necessary permissions to access columns associated with specific policy tags. This configuration ensures that only authorized users based on their roles and responsibilities can view or manipulate sensitive data.
  4. Audit and Monitor Access: Regular auditing and monitoring of access patterns to BigQuery datasets are essential. Utilize tools like Cloud Audit Logs to track who is accessing what data and ensure that the policy tags and IAM permissions are being adhered to effectively.

Implementing policy tags for column-level access control in BigQuery not only heightens data security but also aids in compliance with various regulatory requirements. For more detailed steps and guidance on using policy tags with BigQuery, refer to the BigQuery documentation on best practices for policy tags.

Further information and the latest updates on BigQuery and related services can be found in the official Google Cloud BigQuery documentation.

countermeasure.name: Create perimeter for BigQuery resources
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Google Cloud BigQuery environment, it is highly recommended to use VPC Service Controls to create service perimeters. These perimeters help protect your BigQuery resources by ensuring that they can only be accessed from authorized networks or service accounts. Implementing this control requires careful configuration and management to effectively enforce the intended security policies.

Follow these steps to implement VPC Service Controls for BigQuery:

  1. First, ensure that you have the necessary permissions to create and manage VPC Service Controls and that your organization is appropriately configured to support them.
  2. Create a service perimeter to define the boundary within which your BigQuery resources will reside. Use the Google Cloud Console or gcloud command-line tool for setup. Detailed steps can be found in the Setting up your service perimeter guide.
  3. Within the service perimeter, specify the Google Cloud projects and BigQuery resources that should be protected. This may include specifying the resources in the perimeter's ingress and egress policies.
  4. To further secure your resources, configure Access Level conditions using the Access Context Manager. Access Levels allow you to enforce additional security requirements, such as only allowing access from certain IP ranges or devices.
  5. Test the configuration to ensure that the service perimeter effectively restricts access as intended. Begin by attempting controlled access to confirm whether the perimeter constraints are correctly implemented.
  6. Continuously monitor and update the service perimeter configurations in response to changing security requirements or resource updates.

By following these steps and continuously monitoring your setup, you can help ensure the integrity and security of your BigQuery resources within the VPC Service Controls perimeter.

countermeasure.name: Manage encryption with Cloud KMS
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) for your BigQuery data allows for enhanced control and security of your data at rest. Utilizing CMEK through Google Cloud Key Management Service (Cloud KMS) provides you with the ability to manage and rotate encryption keys, offering a higher level of security customization. Follow these steps to implement CMEK for GCP BigQuery:

  1. Ensure you have the necessary permissions in your Google Cloud project. You must have the roles of roles/bigquery.admin and roles/cloudkms.cryptoKeyUser. Review the detailed roles and permissions at IAM Roles.
  2. Create a key ring and a crypto key in Cloud KMS:
    1. Navigate to the Cloud KMS page in the Google Cloud Console.
    2. Select or create a key ring within your preferred location.
    3. Within this key ring, create a new symmetric encryption key. Refer to Creating and Managing Keys for detailed steps.
  3. Modify your BigQuery dataset to use the CMEK:
    1. Access the BigQuery page on the Google Cloud Console.
    2. Select the dataset you wish to update.
    3. Edit the dataset, specifying the Cloud KMS key resource name you have created. Refer to BigQuery with Customer-Managed Encryption Keys for detailed guidance.
  4. Verify that CMEK is enabled for your dataset by checking the encryption configuration.

Implementing CMEK via Cloud KMS provides you with granular control over the encryption keys used to secure your data at rest, ensuring compliance with stringent security requirements. For further details, please refer to the BigQuery Encryption at Rest documentation.

countermeasure.name: Restrict user permissions to limit side-channel attacks
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that users in your organization are only granted access to data they are authorized to view, avoid assigning sensitive permissions to those who should access filtered data in BigQuery. Instead, implement Row-level security, which allows you to control access to subsets of data within a table.

Follow these steps to implement this security control:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data: Assess your datasets to determine which contain sensitive information that should not be fully exposed to certain users.
  2. Create Row Access Policies: Use SQL expressions to define policies that filter data by rows. This involves creating logical conditions to determine which rows can be accessed by specific groups or roles. For example, create a policy to allow access only to rows where the department ID matches the user's department.
  3. Apply Policies to Tables: Assign these row access policies to the appropriate tables within BigQuery using the ALTER TABLE SET OPTIONS statement. This step ensures that unauthorized users cannot see data beyond their permissions.
  4. Review and Test Policies Regularly: Continually review and test these policies to ensure they function as intended and that there are no lapses in data protection. Use the BigQuery Authorized Views as an additional layer to create secure data views based on policy.
  5. Audit Data Access: Regularly monitor access logs and user activity audits through Google Clouds audit logging to ensure compliance and detect any unauthorized data access attempts.

By adhering to these guidelines and using GCP's built-in security features, you can effectively control and secure data visibility within your BigQuery environment.

countermeasure.name: Set the access policy for a dataset
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your BigQuery datasets, it's critical to implement appropriate IAM roles and permissions. This control helps prevent unauthorized access and ensures that users have only the permissions necessary for their role. Here's how to set it up:

  1. Identify the specific roles needed for your BigQuery datasets. BigQuery provides predefined IAM roles such as Viewer, Editor, and Owner, but custom roles can also be created for more granular permissions.
  2. Assign IAM roles to users, groups, or service accounts based on the principle of least privilege. Only grant permissions that are absolutely necessary for users to perform their tasks. For more details on available roles and permissions, refer to the Access Control documentation.
  3. Use project-level, dataset-level, and table-level permissions to control access. Dataset-level permissions are inherited to tables and views within the dataset, providing a straightforward way to manage access.
  4. Review and audit permissions regularly. Use the IAM policy management tools in GCP to periodically review who has access to what resources.
  5. Consider implementing additional security measures such as VPC Service Controls and Audit Logs to enhance security and monitoring.

Following these steps will help ensure that your BigQuery datasets are securely configured with appropriate access controls, in line with the best practices and guidelines provided by Google Cloud Platform.

countermeasure.name: Use differential privacy
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the risk of re-identification in statistical queries within BigQuery, cloud engineers should implement differential privacy. This privacy-enhancing technology ensures that the analysis of data sets remains insightful while protecting individual data points. Below is a guide to implementing this control:

  1. Understand Differential Privacy:
    Start by familiarizing yourself with the core concepts of differential privacy. It works by adding controlled noise to the results of queries, balancing privacy and accuracy. Refer to the Differential Privacy documentation to understand its implications and usage in BigQuery.

  2. Configure Access Control:
    Before implementing differential privacy, ensure that access to your BigQuery datasets is properly managed. Utilize Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) to control permissions. Review the guidelines on BigQuery Access Control.

  3. Enable Differential Privacy in Queries:
    While crafting queries, apply the differential privacy functions available in BigQuery. These functions will include mechanisms for adding noise to the result, adhering to the privacy models. Utilize instructions from the Performing Analyses with Differential Privacy guide to ensure proper implementation.

  4. Monitor and Audit Queries:
    Implementing differential privacy doesn't eliminate the need for monitoring. Regularly audit access logs and query patterns using the Google Cloud audit infrastructure to detect any anomalies or unauthorized data access.

  5. Stay Informed About Updates:
    As Google Cloud constantly updates its services and features, ensure you stay informed about the latest changes and improvements in differential privacy and other BigQuery functionalities. Regularly check the BigQuery Introduction page for the latest information.

By following these steps, cloud engineers can effectively implement differential privacy in BigQuery, balancing both data utility and protection of individual privacy.

countermeasure.name: Use sensitive data protection to scan data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that sensitive data in BigQuery is properly protected during transmission, it is crucial to regularly inspect and manage the data effectively. The following guidelines detail how a cloud engineer can implement this control:

1. Data Inspection with Data Loss Prevention (DLP):

Utilize Google's Data Loss Prevention API to inspect BigQuery datasets for sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information). By setting up DLP inspection jobs, you can automatically scan datasets and identify sensitive data elements, facilitating proper data protection strategies.

2. Encryption in Transit:

Ensure that sensitive data is encrypted when being transmitted over the network. BigQuery automatically encrypts data in transit using TLS (Transport Layer Security). To enhance security, verify that all communication between your applications and BigQuery employs TLS. Consult the Encryption in Transit documentation for best practices.

3. Access Management:

Implement Strong IAM (Identity and Access Management) roles and permissions to restrict access to sensitive data. Define who can view, query, or manage datasets by setting appropriate roles at the project, data set, or table level. Refer to the BigQuery Access Control documentation for detailed guidance on assigning roles and permissions.

4. Audit Logging:

Enable Audit Logging to monitor access to sensitive data. Analyzing audit logs helps to detect unauthorized access and anomaly patterns, assisting in ensuring compliance with data protection regulations.

Regularly executing these practices not only helps in safeguarding data during transmission but also keeps your organization compliant with security policies and standards. For further information, you can explore more in-depth guidance on GCP's official BigQuery Documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Side-channel attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data might be inferred through patterns observed in query durations or by analyzing billing information, even when row-level access policies are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers scrutinize query execution times or billing records to deduce information about data protected by access controls.
Impacts
Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information that could lead to data breaches, financial loss, or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An adversary consistently monitors the time it takes for different queries to execute, uncovering the presence or absence of sensitive data based on anomalies in query performance or they analyze the variation in billing charges to infer protected data patterns.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium||ATLAS - AML.T0048.000 - Financial Harm

threat.name: Unauthorized access to resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate controls on datasets or tables expose them to potential unauthorized access, which could lead to manipulation or viewing of sensitive information without proper permissions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers or malicious insiders may exploit insufficient access controls, misconfigurations, or use stolen credentials to gain unauthorized access to datasets or tables.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data can result in data breaches, loss of data integrity, privacy violations, and regulatory penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses compromised credentials to log into BigQuery and accesses a dataset containing confidential business analytics. Alternatively, an internal user without proper authorization modifies records in a shared table, leading to data corruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1213 - Data from Information Repositories||ATLAS - AML.T0000 - Search Open Technical Databases

threat.name: Lack of encryption for sensitive data at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive information within a database can be easily accessed or intercepted if it is stored without encryption, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, hackers, or insiders who gain access to systems and purposely exploit weak security controls to access unencrypted data.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, financial loss, legal consequences, damage to reputation, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains entry to a cloud environment through a compromised account and finds that sensitive data within a database is stored in plain text. They easily extract the data without detection, causing a major breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact||ATLAS - AML.T0010.002 - Data

threat.name: Data leakage between perimeters
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data transfers can lead to data leakage, particularly when data moves outside the designated VPC Service Controls perimeters without appropriate authorization. This exposes sensitive or confidential information, violating data privacy policies and security protocols.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents such as malicious insiders or external attackers may use compromised credentials or exploit misconfigured network settings to transfer data outside the secure perimeter. Attack vectors include direct access to the database, exploiting API endpoints, or leveraging cloud services misconfigurations.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage. Such incidents can result in financial losses and legal liabilities for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider with administrative privileges transfers a critical dataset to an external storage service bypassing VPC Service Controls. Alternatively, an external attacker gains access to a compromised account and initiates a data transfer through a misconfigured API endpoint, resulting in sensitive data leaving the organizations protected environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1020 - Automated Exfiltration||ATLAS - AML.T0025 - Exfiltration via Cyber Means

threat.name: Unauthorized data view at column-level
threat.desc:
General threat description
The absence of appropriate policy tags could lead to the inadvertent exposure of sensitive information in datasets stored in the service. This situation can arise when data access controls are not properly defined, leading to unauthorized users gaining access to sensitive data they should not have visibility into.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers exploiting misconfigurations, or even well-intentioned personnel who accidentally access information beyond their authorization. These vectors exploit the lack of adequate data classification and protection mechanisms to access confidential data.
Impacts
The exposure of sensitive data could result in privacy violations, regulatory non-compliance, damage to the organization's reputation, financial losses, or even legal consequences. It may also lead to competitive disadvantage if proprietary information is accessed and misused by unauthorized parties.
Example Attack Scenarios
For instance, if datasets containing personally identifiable information are not properly tagged with the appropriate policies, an unauthorized employee might access this information and misuse it for fraudulent activities or identity theft. Similarly, external attackers could exploit weak access controls to extract sensitive business information or customer details from the datasets.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1213 - Data from Information Repositories||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure through query results
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data in the environment may be viewed by users who do not have adequate permission levels. This exposure occurs when access controls are not properly configured, leading to potential unauthorized data disclosure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers or unauthorized users could exploit misconfigured access controls or permissions to gain visibility to restricted data. This typically involves malicious insiders or external adversaries who leverage insufficient security configurations.
Impacts
The impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, which can lead to data breaches, compliance violations, and loss of business integrity. This exposure could also result in financial losses or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
A data analyst with permissions only for certain datasets might discover a misconfiguration allowing access to confidential datasets, inadvertently or maliciously downloading sensitive information. Alternatively, an outsider who has gained unauthorized access could exploit weak data controls to view and extract sensitive data without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Sensitive information re-identification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental exposure of confidential information via statistical analysis or data aggregation leading to leaks of sensitive data insights.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external contractors running or accessing queries that aggregate data into reports without realizing the potential exposure of sensitive insights.
Impacts
Unauthorized access or disclosure of confidential data could result in compliance violations, erosion of customer trust, and financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee runs a query on aggregated customer spending data and without realizing it, produces results that expose individual customer financial habits, which could be exploited by malicious actors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery||ATLAS - AML.T0048.000 - Financial Harm

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in transit
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data transmitted over network can be intercepted if not properly secured.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or hackers could exploit unsecured network transmissions to intercept sensitive data packets. They may use tools like packet sniffers to capture information flowing over the network if encryption protocols are not adequately implemented.
Impacts
The interception of sensitive data can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and potentially damaging exposure of confidential information. This can result in compliance violations, financial loss, and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker, connected to a public Wi-Fi network, uses a packet sniffer to capture unencrypted data being transmitted from a device to a remote server. This intercepted data includes sensitive personal information, which the attacker can then exploit for identity theft or sell on the dark web.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1040 - Network Sniffing||ATLAS - AML.T0025 - Exfiltration via Cyber Means

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to cloud functions
countermeasure.desc:
Define and implement IAM policies that ensure GCP Cloud Functions are invoked only by authorized users and services. Use the principle of least privilege to grant the minimal set of permissions necessary for each user, service, or application. Regularly review and audit IAM policies to confirm that access is properly restricted and aligned with business needs, and that unnecessary permissions are removed. This control helps protect cloud functions from unauthorized access and potential misuse.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Assign a unique service account to each cloud function
countermeasure.desc:
Configure each GCP Cloud Function to use a unique service account to limit the scope of access and privileges. This practice ensures that each function operates with a dedicated identity, restricting access to only the resources necessary for that specific function. By isolating service accounts, you minimize the risk of privilege escalation and prevent the misuse of elevated permissions across multiple functions. Regularly audit the service accounts and their associated roles to ensure they follow the principle of least privilege.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Identity Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all cloud function endpoints to encrypt data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all GCP Cloud Function endpoints are configured to use HTTPS to secure data transmission and prevent interception. This control mandates the use of encrypted communication channels, ensuring that any data exchanged between your cloud functions and external services is protected from unauthorized access or tampering. Review and configure function triggers to ensure they enforce HTTPS and reject HTTP traffic. Regularly audit your functions to confirm compliance with this security requirement.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Security Documentation

countermeasure.name: Store and retrieve secrets securely using Google Secret Manager
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Secret Manager to securely store and manage sensitive information such as API keys, credentials, and tokens. Configure GCP Cloud Functions to retrieve secrets securely at runtime, ensuring that sensitive data is not hardcoded or exposed in environment variables or code. Regularly audit and rotate secrets to minimize the risk of compromise, and ensure that access to secrets is restricted to only authorized functions or users.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Secret Manager Best Practices

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control on functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate access control on GCP Functions can allow unauthorized users or services to invoke functions, potentially leading to data exposure, service misuse, or unauthorized access to sensitive cloud resources. Misconfigured IAM policies or broad permissions can increase the risk of such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak IAM policies, using over-privileged accounts or services to invoke cloud functions, or brute-forcing unsecured function endpoints.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exploitation, and service disruptions.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to an over-privileged service account and uses it to invoke a sensitive cloud function, exfiltrating data.
  2. A malicious insider with overly broad permissions invokes internal cloud functions to manipulate business-critical processes without detection.

threat.name: Improper use of shared service accounts for functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using shared service accounts for multiple GCP Functions can expose sensitive resources to broader access than necessary, increasing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation. Shared service accounts may accumulate more permissions over time, leading to potential misuse.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised services.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting overly-permissive service accounts used by multiple functions, or compromising a function that has broad access due to a shared service account.

Impacts

  • Privilege escalation, unauthorized access to sensitive resources, data breaches, and potential service disruption.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A compromised cloud function with access to a shared service account is used by an attacker to escalate privileges and access sensitive data in other services.
  2. An insider with access to a shared service account misuses elevated permissions to modify critical cloud infrastructure across multiple functions, bypassing security controls.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Transmitting data between GCP Functions and other services without encryption exposes sensitive information to interception by attackers. Unencrypted communication channels, such as HTTP, allow malicious actors to eavesdrop, manipulate data, or carry out man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, network eavesdroppers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted data over HTTP or other unsecured communication protocols, exploiting weak or misconfigured transport layer security.

Impacts

  • Data breaches, loss of confidentiality, unauthorized access, and data manipulation.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A GCP Function sends sensitive data to an external API over HTTP instead of HTTPS, allowing an attacker to intercept and steal the data using a packet sniffer.
  2. An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted traffic between cloud functions, modifying the data in transit to manipulate the service behavior.

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of secrets, such as API keys, credentials, or tokens within GCP Functions, can lead to unauthorized access if they are exposed or compromised. Storing secrets in unsecured locations, such as environment variables, increases the risk of leaks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting secrets stored in function environment variables, code repositories, or logs, or intercepting unsecured secrets during transmission.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to cloud resources, data breaches, and potential manipulation of services or databases.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A cloud function stores API keys in environment variables, which are accessed by an attacker exploiting a vulnerability in the function, leading to unauthorized access to external services.
  2. A developer inadvertently pushes secrets to a public repository, allowing an attacker to use the compromised secrets to access critical cloud resources.

weakness.name: CWE-1007
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1007: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply Bucket Lock policies to enforce retention periods for stored objects
countermeasure.desc:
Apply Bucket Lock policies in GCP Storage to enforce mandatory retention periods on objects within storage buckets. This prevents any deletion or modification of data during the specified retention period. This security control is essential for protecting critical data from accidental deletions, overwrites, or unauthorized changes. Once configured, the retention period cannot be shortened or removed, offering robust protection for sensitive data that must comply with regulatory or legal retention requirements. Bucket Lock can also be combined with object holds to protect individual objects beyond the retention settings.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Bucket Lock Documentation

reference.name: 2.3 - Ensure That Retention Policies on Cloud Storage Buckets Used for Exporting Logs Are Configured Using Bucket Lock

countermeasure.name: Configure signed URLs to provide time-limited access to storage objects
countermeasure.desc:
Configure signed URLs in GCP Storage to allow time-limited access to specific objects without exposing the entire bucket. Signed URLs provide a secure mechanism to grant temporary access to an object for a defined period, after which the URL expires and access is revoked. This is particularly useful for scenarios where you need to share objects with external users or systems in a controlled manner. By using signed URLs, you ensure that access to sensitive objects is restricted, protecting the storage bucket while still enabling authorized users to retrieve the needed files within a specified time frame.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Signed URLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable object versioning in GCP Storage buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Enable object versioning in GCP Storage to automatically retain prior versions of objects stored in buckets. This feature ensures that whenever an object is modified, deleted, or overwritten, the previous versions remain accessible for recovery. Object versioning is an essential safeguard against accidental deletions or modifications, allowing you to restore earlier versions of files when necessary. This feature is particularly useful in environments where multiple users or automated processes interact with the same objects, reducing the risk of permanent data loss due to human error or unexpected overwrites.

When object versioning is enabled, GCP Storage keeps track of object changes by assigning unique version identifiers to each version of an object. You can access, restore, or even delete specific object versions as needed. This can be configured at the bucket level, and its important to consider implementing version lifecycle management to control the storage cost of maintaining old versions by automatically deleting older versions based on your organizations data retention policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Object Versioning Documentation

countermeasure.name: Use fine-grained access control for object-level permissions in GCP Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage fine-grained access control to enforce more precise, object-level permissions within GCP Storage. Unlike bucket-level permissions, fine-grained control allows you to assign specific roles and access permissions directly to individual storage objects. This ensures that users and services only have the minimum required access to specific data, greatly reducing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, or unintentional modifications. This is particularly useful for environments where different users or services need varying levels of access to objects within the same bucket. For instance, one user might need read access to a subset of objects, while another might require write permissions to other objects. By applying object-level roles, you can tailor security settings to align with your organizations data protection policies, improving overall security and compliance.

Additionally, fine-grained access control integrates with Google Cloud IAM, allowing you to define roles and assign them based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users and services can only interact with data that they are authorized to access. It is also advisable to regularly review and audit permissions to ensure that access remains appropriate over time and does not violate security policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Fine-Grained Access Control Documentation

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A companys storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A companys storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-366
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-366: Race Condition within a Thread If two threads of execution use a resource simultaneously, there exists the possibility that resources may be used while invalid, in turn making the state of execution undefined.

weakness.name: CWE-670
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-670: Always-Incorrect Control Flow Implementation The code contains a control flow path that does not reflect the algorithm that the path is intended to implement, leading to incorrect behavior any time this path is navigated. This weakness captures cases in which a particular code segment is always incorrect with respect to the algorithm that it is implementing. For example, if a C programmer intends to include multiple statements in a single block but does not include the enclosing braces (CWE-483), then the logic is always incorrect. This issue is in contrast to most weaknesses in which the code usually behaves correctly, except when it is externally manipulated in malicious ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply the principle of least privilege using predefined or custom IAM roles
countermeasure.desc:
Create dedicated service accounts and user roles that include only the Vertex AI permissions each workload or engineer absolutely needs, avoiding blanket grants like roles/owner or roles/editor.

  1. map required actions
    • Model training pipelines usually need roles/aiplatform.user plus storage.objectViewer on the specific GCS bucket that stores training data.
    • Online prediction endpoints may need roles/aiplatform.endpointUser and iam.serviceAccountUser on a single execution account.
  2. scope resources
    • When you bind a role, limit it to exact project numbers, model IDs, or endpoints:
      • gcloud projects add-iam-policy-binding my-project \
         --member=serviceAccount:train-svc@my-project.iam.gserviceaccount.com \
         --role=roles/aiplatform.user \
         --condition='resource.name.startsWith("projects/123456/locations/us-central1/trainingPipelines/")'
  3. use custom roles for edge cases
    • If predefined roles grant unused permissions, create a custom role (e.g., vertexTrainingRunner) that contains only aiplatform.trainingPipelines.create and aiplatform.trainingPipelines.get.
  4. enforce with policy analyzer
    • Enable IAM Recommender to surface permissions never exercised in the last 90 days and remove them.
    • Deny future basic-role bindings by setting an Organization Policy constraint (constraints/iam.disableServiceAccountKeyCreation) and an IAM Conditions rule blocking roles/editor.
  5. audit quarterly
    • Export IAM policies (gcloud projects get-iam-policy) and compare against your least-privilege matrix.
    • Rotate or delete dormant service-account keys; prefer Workload Identity Federation or short-lived tokens.

Applying strict, resource-scoped roles curbs blast radius if a credential is compromised and satisfies security-by-design requirements for regulated ML workloads.

References

  • IAM best practices for Vertex AI

countermeasure.name: Encrypt communications between Vertex AI components using TLS
countermeasure.desc:
Make every hop inside your Vertex AI pipelinetraining jobs, prediction requests, and data-plane calls to BigQuery, Cloud Storage, or Custom Container endpointstravel over Transport-Layer Security (TLS) so that data in transit cannot be snooped or altered.

how to implement

  1. use HTTPS for all service endpoints
    • When calling Vertex AI REST or gRPC APIs from your CI pipeline, notebooks, or on-prem clients, always target the https://aiplatform.googleapis.com endpoint or the TLS-secured regional domain.
    • For private-service-connect endpoints inside VPC-SC, keep the default TLS termination enabled; never bypass it with plaintext http:// URLs.
  2. secure custom prediction services
    • If you deploy a custom container on GKE or Cloud Run, expose it behind an HTTPS load balancer that terminates TLS with a Google-managed certificate (RSA-2048/ECDSA-P256) and enforces TLS 1.2+ cipher suites.
    • Inside the cluster, use mTLS (Istio or Anthos Service Mesh) so pod-to-pod traffic stays encrypted.
  3. enable secure-tunnel when connecting to training workers
    • For distributed training on custom Compute Engine VMs, launch the job with the --enable_secure_training flag or set encryptionSpec.kmsKeyName to use CMEK-protected disks and TLS tunnels between workers.
  4. harden client libraries
    • Upgrade Google-cloud Python/Java/Go libraries to the latest version; by default they negotiate TLS 1.3 1.2 and reject SSLv3/TLS 1.0/1.1.
    • Disable insecure cipher suites (RC4, 3DES, static RSA) in the JVM or openssl.cnf used by your containers.
  5. monitor and test
    • Use Cloud Logging Load Balancer logs; filter for tlsProtocol and alert if anything below TLSv1.2 appears.
    • Run weekly SSL scans (openssl s_client -tls1_1) against your custom endpointsensure the handshake fails below TLS 1.2.

Encrypting every connection with modern TLS protects model assets, training data, and prediction payloads, and meets compliance frameworks such as HIPAA, PCI DSS v4, and ISO 27001.

References

  • Customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK)

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information||ATLAS - AML.M0012 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement data validation, sanitization, and provenance tracking before training
countermeasure.desc:
Before any dataset is fed into Vertex AI training pipelines, run it through a staged process that (a) verifies schema and content, (b) cleans or rejects bad records, and (c) records an immutable provenance hash so you can reproduce the model and prove data lineage:

  1. schema & quality validation
    • Store raw files in a landing Cloud Storage bucket with object-level versioning.
    • Trigger a Dataflow or Cloud Data Fusion job that checks column count, data types, value ranges, and reserved keyword lists; fail the pipeline on violations.
  2. sanitization & PII scrubbing
    • Mask or drop fields that contain personal data using Data Loss Prevention (DLP) templates.
    • Reject out-of-range or malformed rows; write them to a quarantine bucket for manual review.
  3. provenance tracking
    • After validation, generate a SHA-256 digest of the cleaned dataset and store itplus metadata like source system, validation ruleset version, and DLP job IDin Artifact Registry or Vertex AI Metadata.
    • Tag the training pipeline with the dataset hash so every model artifact links back to the exact data version.
  4. automate & enforce
    • Build the above steps into a Cloud Build / Cloud Composer workflow; deny aiplatform.trainingPipelines.create unless the request includes a valid provenance tag.
    • Enable Cloud Audit Logs for DLP, Dataflow, and Vertex AI; alert on any direct training call that skips the validation pipeline.

Cleaning the data first and locking its fingerprint into metadata prevents poisoned or non-compliant records from entering the model, simplifies debugging, and meets audit requirements for regulated ML workloads.

References

  • Guidelines for developing high-quality, predictive ML solutions

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1047 - Audit||ATLAS - AML.M0007 - Sanitize Training Data

countermeasure.name: Implement input validation and sanitization on prediction requests
countermeasure.desc:
Insert an input-hardening layer in front of every Vertex AI online-prediction endpoint so that only well-formed, safe data reaches the model:

  • schema enforcement describe each feature in a protobuf/JSON Schema (type, range, allowed enum). Reject requests that are missing required fields, contain extra keys, or violate size limits.
  • value sanitization trim whitespace, normalise Unicode, escape JSON/SQL special characters, and clamp numeric features to expected min-max ranges.
  • pre-invoke guardrail run the validation inside Cloud Functions / Cloud Run (or an API Gateway request validator) that sits in front of projects/.../locations/.../endpoints/*:predict; return HTTP 400 with an error code like INVALID_ARGUMENT if checks fail.
  • logging & alerting write rejected payload hashes (never raw PII) to Cloud Logging and create an alert on spikespossible probing attacks.
  • defence-in-depth for text inputs, strip or encode HTML/JS to mitigate prompt-injection or XSS if the model output is rendered in a UI.
  • automated tests add unit tests and fuzzers (e.g., AFL, Jazzer) that feed malformed or malicious payloads to the validator and assert rejection.
  • continuous review version the schema alongside the model; bump both together and deprecate old schemas on a schedule.

A strict validation/sanitisation layer stops malformed, oversized, or malicious data from crashing the model server, skewing predictions, or exploiting downstream consumers.

References

  • Input data format and structure
  • Input Validation Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1050 - Exploit Protection||ATLAS - AML.M0015 - Adversarial Input Detection

countermeasure.name: Implement secure data processing methods in Vertex AI
countermeasure.desc:
Design every Vertex AI pipelineETL, feature engineering, training, and batch predictionto execute inside hardened, access-controlled resources and handle data only through encrypted, auditable channels.

  1. run pipelines in private VPCs
    • Attach a VPC Network to the pipelines network field so training and Dataflow jobs never traverse the public internet.
    • Use Private Service Connect or VPC-SC to reach BigQuery, Cloud Storage, and Artifact Registry over Googles internal backbone.
  2. enforce CMEK encryption at rest
    • Specify encryptionSpec.kmsKeyName on training jobs, custom jobs, and model artifacts.
    • Store intermediate files in CMEK-protected Cloud Storage buckets; enable bucket-level Uniform Access and turn on Object Versioning.
  3. apply row- and column-level access controls
    • Ingest data from BigQuery tables that have Row-level Security and Column-level Encryption (BQRLS + BQCL).
    • Add Data Loss Prevention (DLP) jobs to mask PII before the dataset enters Feature Store or AutoML.
  4. isolate execution identities
    • Give each pipeline its own service account with the minimal roles (aiplatform.user, dataset-specific bigquery.dataViewer, storage.objectAdmin on the staging bucket).
    • Deny long-lived keys; use Workload Identity Federation for cross-project runs.
  5. log and audit everything
    • Stream Vertex AI audit logs and Dataflow / BigQuery Job logs to Cloud Logging; forward high-severity anomalies to Security Command Center.
    • Enable Vertex AI Metadata to record dataset hashes, training parameters, and lineage for reproducibility.
  6. validate outputs
    • Run a post-processing step that scans generated datasets or model artifacts with DLP to ensure no raw PII leaked into outputs.
    • Store cryptographic checksums and sign model artifacts in Artifact Registry.

Applying these controls keeps sensitive data encrypted, private, and traceable throughout the entire Vertex AI processing lifecycle.

References

  • Vertex AI shared responsibility

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to model artifacts using IAM and VPC Service Controls
countermeasure.desc:
Store every Vertex AI model artifacttraining checkpoints, custom container images, and exported model bundlesin projects that are fenced by VPC Service Controls (VPC-SC) and grant least-privilege IAM access inside that perimeter:

  1. build a VPC-SC perimeter
    • In Google Cloud Console Security VPC Service Controls, create a perimeter that includes the projects hosting your Artifact Registry, Cloud Storage buckets, and Vertex AI resources.
    • Add service restrictions for AI Platform, Artifact Registry, Cloud Storage, and BigQuery so data can move only between projects inside the perimeter.
  2. lock IAM roles to the perimeter
    • Give training pipelines a dedicated service account with roles/aiplatform.user and roles/storage.objectViewer on the specific bucket; do not grant roles/storage.admin or project-wide Editor.
    • Require accessLevels in IAM conditions so even permitted users must connect from a trusted IP / device to download or upload model files.
  3. block egress and import from untrusted projects
    • Enable Domain-restricted Sharing to prohibit Artifact Registry images from being pulled by projects outside your organisation.
    • Use VPC-SC ingress & egress rules to deny CopyObject or ExportModel operations that cross the perimeter boundary.
  4. monitor & alert
    • Stream Access Transparency logs and Cloud Audit Logs to Cloud Logging; create alerts on storage.objects.get or aiplatform.models.export events where the callers project is outside the perimeter.
    • Periodically run IAM Recommender to prune unused permissions on model buckets and registries.
  5. review quarterly
    • Verify that new buckets or registries are added to the perimeter.
    • Rotate service-account keys; prefer Workload Identity Federation so no long-lived keys exist.

Combining VPC Service Controls with tightly scoped IAM roles prevents accidental or malicious leakage of high-value model artifacts while still allowing secure, automated ML workflows.

References

  • VPC Service Controls with Vertex AI

countermeasure.name: Use Artifact Registry with container scanning to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities
countermeasure.desc:
Store all custom-training and prediction container images in Artifact Registry, turn on built-in vulnerability scanning, and block Vertex AI pipelines from pulling an image that still contains unmitigated High or Critical CVEs.

implementation guidance

  1. create a private repository with scanning enabled
    1. gcloud artifacts repositories create vertex-containers \
         --repository-format=docker \
         --location=us-central1 \
         --description="Vertex AI containers" \
         --enable-vulnerability-scanning
  2. integrate scanning into CI/CD
    • After the Cloud Build job pushes an image (gcr.io/... us-central1-docker.pkg.dev/), wait for the scanning status.
    • Fail the pipeline if the scan reports any High/Critical findings that lack a documented waiver:
      • gcloud artifacts docker images list \
           us-central1-docker.pkg.dev/my-proj/vertex-containers \
           --include-tags --format="value(vulnerability_breakdown.critical)"
  3. gate vertex ai jobs
    • Add a policy controller (OPA/Gatekeeper or Cloud Deploy verify step) that refuses to create a CustomJob, TrainingPipeline, or Endpoint if the image digests scan status SUCCESSFUL_VULNERABILITY_SCAN&_NO_HIGH_FINDINGS.
    • For notebook development, allow only images that come from the trusted Artifact Registry repo by denying wildcard docker.io pulls.
  4. continuous monitoring & alerts
    • Artifact Registry re-scans images daily; forward new findings to Security Command Center.
    • Set a Cloud Monitoring alert on the metric Artifact Registry Vulnerabilities Active High severity.
  5. incident response & patching
    • When a new CVE appears, rebuild the base image (e.g., debian:12-slim), bump your Dockerfile FROM line, and repush.
    • Redeploy Vertex AI endpoints with the patched digest; update the image tag pin in your IaC.

Using Artifact Registrys vulnerability scanning and enforcing it as a release gate stops known-bad images from ever reaching Vertex AI, tightening your supply-chain security.

References

  • Artifact analysis and vulnerability scanning
